title: 1950s - Early Computer Graphics
text:
The 1950s marked the beginning of computer graphics as a field. John Whitney, a pioneer in computer graphics, created abstract films using analog computers. In 1958, the film 'Vertigo', directed by Alfred Hitchcock, showcased one of the earliest uses of computer graphics in film, employing a hypnotic spiral effect to represent the protagonist's fear of heights.

 

This effect was created by Saul Bass, a graphic designer and filmmaker known for his distinctive style in title sequences and posters. The spiral effect was achieved using a mechanical analog computer known as the optical printer. This device allowed for the combination of multiple film elements into a single piece of film, using various photographic techniques like matte shots, fades, and color changes. For 'Vertigo,' Bass used a series of mathematically generated spirals and overlaid them on footage of an eye, creating the iconic and disorienting opening sequence. The spirals themselves were produced using a combination of physical mechanisms and photographic tricks, with a rotating spiral pattern filmed against a neutral background.

 

These early experiments laid the foundation for modern computer graphics by demonstrating the potential for technology to create entirely new visual experiences that were impossible with traditional methods alone.
alt: Early computer graphics and the film Vertigo

title: 1960s - Ivan Sutherland's Sketchpad
text: Ivan Sutherland developed Sketchpad in the 1960s, the first graphical user interface and precursor to modern CAD systems. This innovation laid the foundation for interactive computer graphics.
alt: Ivan Sutherland and the Sketchpad program

title: 1970s - Development of 3D Graphics
text: Ed Catmull, a co-founder of Pixar, developed foundational techniques in 3D graphics, including texture mapping and Z-buffering, allowing for more realistic rendering of 3D objects.

title: 1980s - Evolution of Neural Networks and Ray Tracing
text: Neural networks gained attention in the 1980s, with the rediscovery of backpropagation, essential for training neural networks. Graphics techniques like ray tracing, introduced by Turner Whitted, enabled photorealistic rendering.
alt: Rise of neural networks and ray tracing

title: 1990s - Rise of Generative Art and Digital Media
text: The 1990s saw the rise of digital media and generative art. Artists began using algorithms to create digital artwork, with fractal algorithms generating complex, self-similar patterns.
alt: Generative art and digital media in the 1990s

title: 2000s - Rise of Internet
text: The 1990s saw the rise of digital media and generative art. Artists began using algorithms to create digital artwork, with fractal algorithms generating complex, self-similar patterns.
alt: Generative art and digital media in the 1990s

title: 2006 - Youtube
text: The 1990s saw the rise of digital media and generative art. Artists began using algorithms to create digital artwork, with fractal algorithms generating complex, self-similar patterns.
alt: Generative art and digital media in the 1990s

title: 2010s - Rise of Social Media
text: The 1990s saw the rise of digital media and generative art. Artists began using algorithms to create digital artwork, with fractal algorithms generating complex, self-similar patterns.
alt: Generative art and digital media in the 1990s

title: 2014 - Birth of Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs)
text: Ian Goodfellow introduced GANs in 2014, a method that pitted two neural networks against each other to produce realistic images, revolutionizing fields like computer vision, art, and game development.
alt: Introduction of GANs by Ian Goodfellow

title: 2015 - Variational Autoencoders (VAEs) and Latent Space Exploration
text: VAEs provided a probabilistic approach to generating images, complementing GANs with a simpler framework for exploring latent spaces and generating new data points.

title: 2017 - Introduction of Transformer Architecture
text: Google's 'Attention Is All You Need' paper introduced the Transformer architecture, revolutionizing natural language processing (NLP) and forming the backbone of models like GPT and BERT.

title: 2020 - Emergence of Diffusion Models
text: Researchers like Robin Rombach introduced diffusion models, a new approach to generative modeling that gradually transforms data distributions using a diffusion process, initially used for detailed and consistent image synthesis.
alt: Emergence of diffusion models in generative AI

title: 2021 - CLIP and Prompt Engineering
text: OpenAI introduced CLIP, a model that understands both images and text. CLIP's ability to align images with text improved prompt understanding, enhancing models like DALL-E in generating images from textual descriptions.

title: 2022 - Latent Diffusion and the road to Democratization of AI Tools
alt: Release of Stable Diffusion by Stability AI

title: 2022 - ControlNet and Enhanced Control Over Image Generation
text: Stable Diffusion, developed by Stability AI and led by Emad Mostaque, was released as an open-source diffusion model. It democratized access to powerful AI tools, enabling widespread experimentation and innovation.
alt: Introduction of ControlNet for enhanced image generation control

title: 2023 - ControlNet and Enhanced Control Over Image Generation
text: ControlNet, developed by researchers like Lvmin Zhang, added conditional controls to diffusion models, allowing for precise manipulation of generated images based on poses, edges, and depth maps. This marked a significant advancement in customized image generation.
alt: Introduction of ControlNet for enhanced image generation control

title: 2023 - Rise of Fine-Tuned Models and Civitai Platform
text: The Civitai platform emerged as a hub for fine-tuned models, allowing users to customize AI models for specific tasks. The rise of fine-tuned models, based on popular frameworks like Stable Diffusion, empowered users to tailor models for their unique needs.
alt: Rise of fine-tuned models and Civitai platform

title: 2023 - Diffusion Models in Mainstream Applications
text: Diffusion models became mainstream in 2023, widely adopted for various generative tasks, from text-to-image generation to video synthesis and drug discovery, solidifying their place in the AI landscape.

title: 2024 - FLUX.1 and Further Innovations in Diffusion Models
text: FLUX.1, developed by Black Forest Labs, introduced new techniques in diffusion models that improved computational efficiency and image quality. It represented a state-of-the-art approach in the evolving landscape of generative AI.
alt: Introduction of FLUX.1 by Black Forest Labs
